scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-1006 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-1006 is a star with 0.78 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.74 times its radius. It is located NaN light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 4.27 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-1006 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-1006 system


Kepler-1006 b

Kepler-1006 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2016-05, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-1006 b is 2.989 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-1006 b is 1.540 that of Earth. At 2.989 Earth masses, Kepler-1006 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-1006, which contains 1 exoplanets and was discovered by the Kepler.
name: Kepler-1006 - System With 1 Exoplanet
